summary: This document is a chain of emails from October 2020 and July 2019 regarding the scanning and processing of approximately 22 boxes of evidence from FBI case files related to the Jeffrey Epstein investigation, in preparation for discovery in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The correspondence discusses logistical issues, missing items, the discovery of pornographic images of young girls that were not scanned per protocol, and the handling of digital discs found in the files.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.context: A prosecutor from the Southern District of New York working on the Epstein investigation, coordinating the evidence scanning process for discovery in the Maxwell case.

events.title: Completion of Evidence Inventory
events.description: The team finished inventorying all 22 boxes of evidence and released them to DocLab for scanning.

events.title: Discovery of Unscanned Pornographic Images
events.description: During scanning, pornographic images of young girls were identified and not scanned per protocol, with notations left in the files.

events.title: Prior Evidence Scanning by Miami Field Office
events.description: The Miami Field Office had previously requested scanning of some of the evidence boxes in 2013.

events.title: Follow-up on Evidence Scanning for Maxwell Discovery
events.description: Prosecutors follow up on questions from 2019 regarding the labeling of copied discs and the location of unscanned pornographic images, as discovery is underway in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

keyFacts: Approximately 22 boxes of evidence from FBI case files 72-MM-113327 and 31E-MM-108062 related to the Jeffrey Epstein investigation were being processed for discovery in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.
Pornographic images of young girls were found in the evidence and were not scanned per protocol; notations were made in the files stating 'possible child pornography DO NOT SCAN.'

Digital discs containing PDFs, JPGs, GIFs, and TIF files were found scattered throughout the evidence boxes; they were copied but not processed, with four copies made of each disc as standard procedure.
Some 1A documents (1A10, 1A28, 1A84) and serials in 31E-MM-108062 were missing from their file jackets, possibly between 2013 and 2015, and had to be regenerated from digital copies.
The evidence scanning was under time pressure with an original deadline of July 10, 2019, but was extended due to the volume of boxes and the July 4th holiday.
